description: Borrowed from Late Latin assimilātus, variant of Latin assimulātus (“made similar, imitated”), perfect passive participle of assimulō, from ad + simulō (“imitate, copy”), from similis (“like, similar”), ultimately from Proto-Indo-European *sem- (“together, one”). Doublet of assemble.

entries.meaning: Something that is or has been assimilated.

verbs.description: assimilate (third-person singular simple present assimilates, present participle assimilating, simple past and past participle assimilated)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To incorporate nutrients into the body, especially after digestion.
examples: Food is assimilated and converted into organic tissue.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To incorporate or absorb (knowledge) into the mind.
examples: The teacher paused in her lecture to allow the students to assimilate what she had said.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To absorb (a person or people) into a community or culture.
examples: The aliens in the science-fiction film wanted to assimilate human beings into their own race.

entries.meaning: (transitive, rare, used with "to" or "with") To liken, compare to something similar.
(transitive) To bring to a likeness or to conformity; to cause a resemblance between.
examples: to assimilate our law in respect to the law of Scotland

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To be incorporated or absorbed into something.
